facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 388 of 1956 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 388 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 19, 1955, of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 53 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the August 19, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 53 of 1955. K. Dhaphtary, Solicitor-General of India, K. B. Choudhuri and B. H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent carries on business in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: A few facts are necessary to be stated to understand the matters in companytroversy and the points raised for our decision. The respondent carries on business in Bombay and he was granted on August 18, 1954, a licence under the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, for the import of fountain-pens at number less than Rs. 25 C.I.F. value each from soft currency area, up to a defined amount.

facts.text: Respondent granted licence on August 18, 1954, under Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947, for import of fountain-pens not less than Rs. 25 C.I.F. value each from soft currency area.

anchor.surface_text: and he was granted on August 18, 1954, a licence under the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, for the import of fountain-pens at number less than Rs. 25 C.I.F. value each from soft currency area, up to a defined amount. He placed an order for the import of Sheaffer pens from Australia and a companysignment of these was received by air in Bombay in Octo- ber 1954.

facts.text: Respondent placed order for import of Sheaffer pens from Australia, consignment received by air in Bombay in October 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He placed an order for the import of Sheaffer pens from Australia and a companysignment of these was received by air in Bombay in Octo- ber 1954. The fountain-pens thus imported had nibs which were gold plated and also caps and clips of similar companyposition.

facts.text: Imported fountain-pens had nibs which were gold plated and caps and clips of similar composition.

anchor.surface_text: The fountain-pens thus imported had nibs which were gold plated and also caps and clips of similar companyposition. The question in companytroversy relates to the rate of duty to be charged on these im. ported pens.

facts.text: Schedule to Indian Tariff Act, 1934, item 45(3) for fountain pens complete at 30 per cent ad valorem.

anchor.surface_text: The Schedule to the Indian Tariff Act, 1934, has an item numbered 45 3  in relations to the article described, as fountain pens companyplete, the rate of duty being 30 per cent and valorem.

facts.text: Respondent claimed imported goods fell within item 45(3) liable to 30% duty.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of the respondent that the imported goods fell within this item and were liable to be charged with duty at that rate.

facts.text: Customs authorities considered consignment fell within item 61(8) articles plated with gold or silver at 78 3/4 per cent duty.

anchor.surface_text: The Custom authorities, however, companysidered that the companysignment fell within the description articles plated with gold or silver being item 61 8  on which duty was payable at 781 per cent.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs adjudicated duty on item 61(8) basis.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Customs adjudicated the duty on this latter basis and thereafter the respondent having filed an appeal to the Collector of Customs, the levy was upheld by order dated February 22, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Collector of Customs, levy upheld by order dated February 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the respondent having filed an appeal to the Collector of Customs, the levy was upheld by order dated February 22, 1955. Section 191 of the Sea Customs Act enables any person aggrieved by an order of the Collector of Customs to file a revision to the Central Government.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ application in Bombay High Court instead of revision under Section 191 Sea Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, without resorting to this remedy, filed a writ application in the High Court of Bombay to quash the imposition of the duty at the higher rate  certiorari  and to direct the release of the goods on payment of duty at 30 per cent.  mandamus .

facts.text: Tendolkar J. by order dated July 5, 1955, allowed writ petition, held duty at 30% under item 45(3).

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition came on for hearing before justice Tendolkar, who by his order dated July 5, 1955, recorded that on any reasonable companystruction of the items in the Schedule to the Indian Customs Tariff, fountain-pens did number cease to be fountain-pens because they companytained parts which were plated with silver or gold

facts.text: Collector of Customs appealed to Division Bench of Bombay High Court, appeal dismissed on August 19, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Customs filed an appeal against this order which was disposed of by a judgment delivered on behalf of the Bench, by Chagla, C. J. ... The appeal was, therefore, dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to Collector of Customs.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Customs having obtained special leave from this Court has brought this appeal before US.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees that imported fountain pens liable to 30% duty under item 45(3), not 78 3/4% under 61(8).

anchor.surface_text: We might add that even apart from this companycession bay for the purpose of argument, we entirely agree with the learned Judges that the tariff items in the Schedule are number reasonably capable of any other companystruction.

facts.text: Fountain-pens complete were taken out of general item 45 Stationery by amendment in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In reaching this companyclusion we have taken into account the fact that fountain-pens companyplete were taken out of the general item 45 Stationery etc. under which they were originally included, by an amendment effected in 1949

facts.text: Duty on fountain pens remained 30% unchanged.

anchor.surface_text: the duty of 30 per cent. fixed on fountain-pens re- mained unchanged.

facts.text: Most fountain-pens in ordinary use have gold-plated nibs.

anchor.surface_text: Next it is a well-known and recognized fact that most fountain-pens in ordinary use have nibs Which are gold-plated.

facts.text: Pens permitted to be imported not less than Rs. 25 C.I.F. value each.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us it would be numbericed that the pens permitted to be imported had to be number less than Rs. 25 each C.I.F. value,

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue issued ruling that fountain-pens with gold-plated nibs or caps fall within item 61(8).

anchor.surface_text: it was stated by the Customs authorities in answer to the writ petition, in the grounds of appeal to the High Court under the Letters Patent, as also in the statement of case before us, that the Central Board of Revenue had issued a ruling to the effect that fountain-pens with nibs or caps which were gold-platled fell within item61 8 .

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Sarkar J. would allow the appeal, holds gold plated fountain pens properly assessed under item 61(8).

anchor.surface_text: I think, therefore, that the assessment in the present case under item 61 8  was proper. I would hence allow the appeal.

holdings.text: Tariff items in the Schedule are not reasonably capable of any other construction placing gold-plated fountain pens outside item 45(3); liable to 30% duty.

anchor.surface_text: We might add that even apart from this concession made for the purpose of argument, we entirely agree with the learned Judges that the tariff items in the Schedule are not reasonably capable of any other construction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with High Court textual construction; considers history of 1949 amendment separating fountain pens from stationery at unchanged 30% duty; judicial notice of common gold-plating on pens; import licence value indicates typical pens have such plating.

holdings.text: Existence of alternative statutory remedy does not bar High Court jurisdiction under Art. 226 but is a rule of policy, convenience and discretion.

anchor.surface_text: We must, however, point out that the rule that the party who applies for the issue of a high prerogative writ should, before he approaches the Court, have exhausted other remedies open to him under-the law, is not one which bars the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain the petition or to deal with it, but is rather a rule which Courts have laid down for the exercise of their discretion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents like Union of India v. T.R. Varma, State of U.P. v. Mohammad Nooh; exceptions not exhaustive; discretion vests in High Court based on facts.

holdings.text: High Court discretion to entertain writ despite alternative remedy not improperly exercised; no interference under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The question that we have now to consider is has the discretion which undoubtedly vested in the Court been so improperly exercised as to call for our interference with that order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous levy manifest; departmental ruling indicates possible futility; no miscarriage of justice; peculiar circumstances justify no interference.

holdings.text: Customs authorities' order assessing duty at 78 3/4% under item 61(8) erroneous but not void for lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: First we entirely agree with Chagla, C. J. that the order of the Assistant Collector of Customs in assessing duty at 781 per cent. or of the Collector of Customs in confirming the same, was not void for lack of jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error in interpretation within exercise of jurisdiction, not lack thereof.

holdings.text: Petitioner not absolved from exhausting remedies merely because time-barred by own delay.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, as we have already indicated, we must express our dissent from the reasoning by which the learned Judges of the High Court held that the writ petitioner was absolved from the normal obligation to exhaust his statutory remedies before invoking the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent from High Court reasoning on time-bar; self-inflicted delay no excuse per Mohammad Nooh.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; no case for interference under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court discretion proper on facts.

holdings.text: Mandamus inappropriate for quasi-judicial customs duty assessment; should direct performance of duty, not dictate outcome.

anchor.surface_text: Next, I feel the gravest doubt if the case is one for the issue of a writ of mandamus. It is of interest to observe that the respondent had in his petition to the High Court himself asked for a writ of certiorari.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty to classify items and levy duty is quasi-judicial per Sea Customs Act ss.29,31,32, appeals; mandamus only to compel hearing/decision, not specific result.

holdings.text: Gold-plated fountain pens properly assessed under item 61(8), not 45(3); specific-over-general rule inapplicable as items do not completely overrule each other.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Item 61(8) applies to all gold-plated articles except specified; 45(3) to fountain pens simpliciter; harmonious construction; policy avoids rendering 61(8) ineffective.

holdings.text: Writ should be refused for failure to exhaust s.191 revision remedy; time-bar self-inflicted no excuse; prior departmental ruling not presumption of futility.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is, whether the writ should have been refused on the ground that the respondent had another remedy, namely, an application to the Central Government under s. 191 of the Sea Customs Act to revise the order of the Collector.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Normal rule requires exhaustion; stronger for statutory duties; no departure without pursuit.

anchor.surface_text: We must, however, point out that the rule that the party who applies for the issue of a high prerogative writ should, before he approaches the Court, have exhausted other remedies open to him under-the law, is not one which bars the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain the petition or to deal with it, but is rather a rule which Courts have laid down for the exercise of their discretion.
